journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: An analysis of flow and heat transfer in separated flows over blocked surface

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Uludag, Turkey
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Harran, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: O Yemenici, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Uludag, 16059 Bursa, Turkey. Email: oseckin@uludag.edu.tr

abstract.p: The flow and heat transfer characteristics of flat and blocked surfaces were experimentally examined under the influence of the free stream velocity of 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s encompassing laminar, transitional and turbulent flows. A constant-temperature hot wire anemometer was used for the velocity and turbulent intensity measurements, and copper-constant thermocouples and a micro-manometer for temperature and static pressures measurements, respectively. The flow over blocked surface separated in front of the first block and attached on it, then circulated between blocks, and then reattached behind the last block. The results showed that the flow separation before the first block occurred earlier in laminar–laminar separated–reattached flow than the transitional and turbulent flows and turbulent–turbulent separated–reattached flow leading to a shorter reattachment region with high free-stream turbulence. The presence of the separation and reattachment caused the heat transfer enhancement, which was more pronounced in the laminar flow and new empirical equations were developed for the local Stanton numbers.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The investigation of flow and heat transfer characteristics of blocked surfaces attracts much interest because of its wide applications in many industrial systems, such as heat exchangers, electronic cooling systems, biomedical devices and nuclear reactors. The presence of blocks increase fluid mixing and interrupt the development of the thermal boundary layer, leading to enhancement of heat transfer. However, it is difficult to understand the flow behavior and heat transfer evolution due to the complex flow features: the boundary layer separation, reattachment and recirculation.

Many investigations of the blocked surface have been carried out to provide information concerning effects of the free stream velocity and geometric parameters on separated flow and heat transfer. A numerical investigation of forced convective cooling of an array of obstacles was performed to synthesize the effects of various parameters on the cooling performance by Zeng and Vafai,1 and they developed two empirical correlations for Nusselt numbers. Miyake et al.2,3 carried out two numerical studies on the turbulent flow in channels with rib-roughened wall, and offered that the major effect of the roughness element was to enhance the turbulent mixing and heat exchange. A new effort to improve the prediction of turbulence and heat transfer in the recirculating region behind an obstacle was discussed by Suga,4 and encouraging results were obtained. Chen and Wang5 experimentally and numerically examined the forced convective flow over two sequentially heated blocks, and they compared the experimental and numerical results and discussed the effect of the block spacing on heat transfer. The turbulent flow in a channel with transverse rib roughness was investigated numerically by Cui et al.,6 who reported that the rib roughness elements imposed their own characteristic length scales on near-wall flow structures. Asako and Faghri7 performed an analysis for laminar flow through an array of heated square blocks, and they reported that the local heat flux on the top surface of block was higher than those on the front, side and rear surfaces. A numerical investigation of flow stability and heat transfer in a channel with grooved parts was carried out by Adachi and Uehara.8 Bilen et al.9 performed an experimental investigation on the effect of orientation angle and geometrical position of wall mounted rectangular blocks, and they indicated that the most efficient parameters were the Reynolds number and orientation angle. The effect of free-stream turbulence on flows over obstacles was analyzed by Terekhov and Yarygina,10 who indicated that the effect of enhanced free-stream turbulence on the separated flow was much more pronounced than that of flat surface. Farhadi and Sedighi11 carried out a numerical study to identify the features of flow past two in-line wall-mounted cubes in a channel for Reynolds number 22000, and indicated that the flow had very complex phenomena such as several horse shoe vortices and recirculation regions. The heat transfer characteristics of a turbulent flow in channels with two-dimensional ribs and three-dimensional blocks were investigated by Ryu et al.,12 who indicated that the different block arrangements exhibit distinct flow characteristics and heat transfer, which were higher than those of the flat surface. Eslami et al.13 studied the laminar fluid flow around two wall-mounted cubes of arbitrary configuration, and found that as Re number increases, the reattachment point behind the second cube goes further. A simulation was presented for a backward-facing step flow and heat transfer inside a channel with ribs turbulators for Reynolds numbers up to 32000 by Mushatet,14 who reported that the Reynolds number and contraction ratio have a significant effect on the variation of turbulent kinetic energy and Nusselt number. Tsay et al.15 carried out a numerical analysis on the performance of mixed convection in a duct with two heated blocks and baffles arranged on the up plate, and found that the heat transfer performance was significantly affected the baffles. The effect of thermal boundary conditions on numerical heat transfer predictions in rib-roughened passages was investigated by Iaccarino et al.,16 who recorded that the heat transfer was dominated by convection upstream and conduction downstream of the rib. Two turbulence models were used to predict the forced convection of a turbulent flow in a channel with uniformly spaced rectangular ribs by Luo et al.,17 and a decay of the heat transfer rate was detected along the streamwise direction over the ribbed surfaces. Influence of rib height and arrangement on the local heat transfer distribution and pressure drop in a ribbed channel was examined experimentally by Sri Harsha et al.,18 who indicated that the heat transfer augmentations in channel with attached ribs increased with rib height. The laminar and turbulent flows and heat transfer characteristics over blocked surfaces under the influence of block height were investigated by Yemenici et al.,19 who indicated that the reattachment length behind the last block and heat transfer increased with block height.

Although many papers have been published to investigate the flow and heat transfer characteristics over blocked surfaces in the literature, most of them were studied separately, numerically and for only one flow structure.In the present study, the flow behavior over blocked surface is investigated experimentally together with the heat transfer characteristics for the free stream velocity of 3 m/s in laminar flow, 5 and 10 m/s in transitional flow and 15 m/s in turbulent flow to provide quantitative knowledge concerning all flow structures that corresponding the block height Reynolds number (Reh) of 4.8 × 103, 7.9 × 103, 1.6 × 104 and 2.4 × 104, respectively.

sec.title: Experimental set-up and data reduction
sec.p: The experimental setups, measuring equipmentand methods, data reductions and uncertainty analysis are explained in this section.

sec.title: The wind tunnel
sec.p:
Flow and heat transfer measurements were carried out on a blowing-type, low-speed wind tunnel, which was run by a 5.7 kW axial fan. The tunnel had 30 m/s maximum velocity with a turbulent intensity of 0.7% and the flow rate was controlled by a butterfly valve. As shown in Figure 1, air passes through a metal duct, a nozzle and a straight duct before the test section. A honey comb was placed at the end of the metal duct to obtain straight streamlines and reduce turbulence level. After the metal duct a nozzle with 1.5:1 contraction ratio was used to prevent the boundary layer separation and to accelerate flow, and then a straight duct was set to achieve a uniform velocity profile. The test section (800 mm long × 240 mm wide × 200 mm height) has a plexiglass side surface to see the flow area and a upper surface with a longitudinal channel to move the measuring instruments in the area. Figure 1.
Wind tunnel and test section.

sec.title: The test surfaces
sec.p:
Primarily, the experiments were carried out over a copper flat plate, which was 750 mm long, 240 mm wide and 0.8 mm thick, and all measurements were performed at streamwise x-locations of 30, 75, 195, 315, 435, 555 and 675 mm. A copper-blocked surface with a sequence of 6 blocks, a surface width (W) of 240 mm, a block height (h) of 25 mm and width (w) of 30 mm, a distance between blocks (s) of 30 mm, a distance between initial of the test section and the first block (L) of 60 mm and a streamwise length of 450 mm were used for the measurements of separated flows, as shown in Figure 2(a). The dimensions of blocked surface were chosen to obtain the same total surface area of the flat surface, and all measurements were carried out at distance of 5 mm in the streamwise direction and 1 mm in the pitchwise direction, as detailed in Figure 6. The ratio of the channel height to the block height (blockage ratio) was calculated as H/h = 8, which was large and satisfactory not to influence the separated boundary layer. The silicon-coated chrome-nickel resistive wire knittingwere furnished backside of the surfaces to obtain the near constant heat flux condition, which was regulated with a variable AC voltage controller and the heat loss was minimized by fiberglass insulation (Figure 2(a)), and the static pressure tappings with a diameter of 0.8 mm were opened on all surfaces (Figure 2(b)). Figure 2.
Heated blocked surface assembly, and thermocouples and pressure tapping details.
Figure 6.
Dimensionless velocity profiles of blocked surface at U = 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s.

sec.title: The measuring equipment
sec.p:
The static pressure measurements were performed using the pressure tappings and capillary pipes, and recorded by a micro-manometer, while the temperatures were measured by copper-constant thermocouples, which were mounted backside of the surfaces at distance of 15 mm in the streamwise and spanwise directions and recorded with a data logger, as seen in Figure 2(b). A constant temperature hot wire anemometer comprised a model P11 probe with probe support and cable, a constant temperature anemometer (CTA), a signal conditioner, an A/D converter, and a computer was used to measure the velocity and turbulent intensities, as shown in Figure 3. A probe with single sensor wire (DANTEC 55P11) and 1D probe support (DANTEC 55H20) were used for the velocity and turbulent intensity measurements. Voltage signals from the CTA with bridge ratio 1:20 were low-pass filtered at 1.25 kHz using an amplifier/filter unit (DANTEC 90N10). An A/D board card (NI-PCI-MIO-16 E-4) was used to acquire the instantaneous velocity signals for a period of 15 s at a sampling frequency of 2500 Hz. The anemometer data were obtained by a CTA application software (Streamware) and the three-dimensional movements of the probe were provided by a lightweight traverse system that was controlled from a computer. A dedicated probe calibrator (DANTEC 90H020) with a low-turbulent free jet, whose velocity is calculated on basis of the pressure drop over its exit, was used and calibration curves fitted by a polynomial trend line in fourth order were obtained to correct and rapid experiment results. Figure 3.
CTA measuring chain.
CTA: constant temperature anemometer.

sec.title: Data reduction
sec.p: The boundary layer over flat plate defined by streamwise distance Reynolds numbers Rex=Ux/ν, momentum thickness Reynolds number Reθ=Uθ/ν, shape factor Hs=δ*/θ and shape factor intermittency factor γHs=(Hs-Hs,L)/(HT-HL) obtained from experimental velocity profiles were compared with the Blasius and Prandtl (1/7)th power law profiles, where momentum thickness was expressed by θ=∫0δu/U(1-u/U)dy. The turbulent intensities and static pressure coefficients of both the flat and blocked surface were calculated by Tu = 100xurms/U and CP = (P − P0)/0.5ρU2, respectively. The location of separation and reattachment points over blocked surface were obtained by determination of mean zero velocity in experimental velocity profiles, like the method applied by Atli20 and confirmed with turbulent intensity and pressure coefficient profiles.

The convection heat loss was estimated from the difference between the flow-off (qo = VoIo/A) and flow-on (qf = VfIf/A) powers required to maintain locally constant wall temperature with and without flow, where V and I are the voltage and current values. The heat transfer coefficients, Stanton numbers and dimensionless wall temperatures were defined by hc = (qf − qo)/(Tw − T0), St = hc/ρUCp and Θw = (Tw − T0)/(Tin − T0), respectively. The experimental Stanton numbers of flat plate were compared with the laminar analytical solutions (equation (1)) and the turbulent approximate methods (equation (2)), which were stated by Kays and Crawford21 for constant heat flux, and also with blocked surface values. (1)Stx=0.453Rex-0.5Pr-0.666(1-(x1/x)0.75)-0.333 (2)Stx=0.030Rex-0.2Pr-0.4(1-(x1/x)0.9)-0.111
The unheated starting lengths (xl) were calculated by Blasius’ analytical method of xl=(U/0.44ν)θ30mm2- 0.030 and the Stanton number intermittency factors by γSt=(St-StL)/(StT-StL).

Kline and McClintock22 uncertainty estimation method was applied for all the measurements of velocity, pressure and temperature and in the determination of the Reynolds numbers, pressure coefficients and Stanton numbers owing to the results to be used to their fullest value. The individual errors in the measurements of velocity were based on instrumentation, calibration equipment and experimental conditions. The traverse system has a resolution better than 0.01 mm and can be repositioned within ±0.1 mm. The calibrator has an accuracy of ±1% and the hotwire calibration error due to curve fitting is within ±0.5%. The maximum uncertainty of the velocity measurements was obtained as ±2.2% considering the electronic noise, probe positioning, A/D resolution and environmental condition errors. The maximum uncertainty in the measurements of pressure caused by manometer slope error of ±0.5°, reading error of ±0.25 mm and surface stresses and random experimental errors was ±4.5%. The contingence error in measuring the surface temperature was estimated to be ±0.5°C, and the maximum uncertainty of the temperature measurements was ±2.8%, based on the contingence, convector card, connection and also experimental errors. The overall uncertainty in the Reynolds number, pressure coefficient and Stanton number were calculated as ±2.3%, ±4.8% and ±3.9%, respectively.

An energy balance check was performed to confirm the experiment results. The control volume that consists of the inflow and outflow plane and the heated surface was used in the first term of the energy balance equation, and the net heat transfer rate (Qnet) from the heated surface to air was calculated as the difference in enthalpy between the inlet and exit of the control volume. The control volume that comprises the test surface was also selected to the second term of the energy balance equation, and Qnet from the test surface was discounted as the total heat loss from the surface was subtracted to the electrical power. The maximum average heat loss obtained was approximately 7% and the first and second terms were within±4% of each other.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: All measurements over the flat and blocked surface were carried out at U = 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s to investigate the effects of free stream velocities on the flow and heat transfer characteristics.

The velocity measurements of the flat plate were presented in non-dimensional form at first (x = 30 mm) and last (x = 675 mm) station, and compared with the laminar velocity profiles of Blasius and turbulent profiles of 1/7 power law. The measured velocity profiles agree with the Blasius profile at 3 m/s, remained between those of Blasius and 1/7 power law at 5 and 10 m/s, and approached the profile of 1/7 power law at 15 m/s, as shown in Figure 4(a) to (d). The boundary layer profile over flat plate in streamwise direction approached those of 1/7 power law due to the effect of friction forces, which push the flow transition to turbulent with increasing free stream velocity. The upper limit from laminar to turbulent on Rex is about 106, while the laminar and turbulent flat plate shape factor (Hs) are 2.6 and 1.3, respectively. To determine the general structure of the boundary layer – laminar, transitional or turbulent – the intermittency factor (γ) was also used, where the values close to 0 and 1 indicate laminar and turbulent flows, respectively. The Hs, Reθ, Rex and γH values of last station remained in laminar region at U = 3 m/s as 2.45, 537, 5.1 × 105 and 0.081 respectively, in turbulent region at 15 m/s with 1.31, 2028, 4.3 × 106 and 0.93, and in transitional region at 5 and 10 m/s, having values of those of the laminar and turbulent regions, similar to the results of Umur et al.23 Figure 4.
Dimensionless velocity profiles over flat plate at U = 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s.

The measured Stanton numbers of the flat plate were in harmony with those of the laminar analytical solutions at 3 m/s and the turbulent approximate methods at 15 m/s, and between the analytical and the approximate method values at 5 and 10 m/s, as seen in Figure 5(a) to (d) and agree with the velocity profiles. The experimental St moved towards the turbulent approximate methods curves (equation (2)) with increasing velocity and the streamwise distance due to the flow being close to the turbulent. The values of γSt were calculated in the range of 0.016–0.089, 0.50–0.55, 0.83–0.90 and 0.94–0.98 in streamwise direction at 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s, respectively, which were higher than γH values because of the movement of the hot fluid on the heated surface towards the center of the flow. Figure 5.
Streamwise variations of Stanton numbers over flat plate at U = 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s.

The dimensionless velocity profiles over the blocked surface in laminar, transitional and turbulent flows are shown in Figure 6(a) to (d). In all measurements, the flow separated before the first block and formed a conjunct separation region, which had the length of 1.2 h, 0.9 h, 0.8 h and 0.6 h (XF) with increasing free stream velocity, so that the turbulent flow was more resistive to separation than the other flows. The maximum free stream velocities that increased 30% in laminar, 20% in transitional and 5% in turbulent flow were obtained at the initial corner of the first block because of the contraction and impact effects. The ratios of the blocks height to the boundary layer thickness (h/δx = 60 mm) were calculated as 1.47, 1.56, 1.67 and 1.92 at U = 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s, respectively. The flow attachment on the first block took place at 1.1 h (XT) for all free stream velocities, similar to the results of Igarashi and Takasaki.24 The near-zero velocities in the cavities proved that all cavities were filled with separation regions, which resembled each other periodically. The recirculation regions formed behind the last block due to the instant expansion and less momentum, and a flow similar to backward step flow was obtained. The reattachment lengths (XR) were determined as 6.7 h in laminar, 6.45 h and 6.55 h in transitional, and 6.3 h in turbulent flow, which were smaller than those of the results of Tariq et al.25 The results showed that the reattachment region length of the turbulent separated–reattached flow was lower than those of the laminar and transitional flows, because high free-stream turbulence shortened the length of the separated region behind the last block.

The velocity profiles in wall coordinates at different streamwise locations for U = 15 m/s is given in Figure 7. The profiles were obtained at x/h = 7.2 and 9.6 where the flow was not affected by the reattachment region and x is a coordinate measured from the ending corner of the last block. The measurements were not reported at below the y-location corresponding to u/U<0.6 because of unreliable region, as stated by Panigrahi and Acharya.26 The velocity profiles in wall coordinates after the reattachment region approached the turbulent law of the wall profile of the flat plate, and the shapes of the profiles evolved in the streamwise direction. Figure 7.
Velocity profiles in wall coordinates at different streamwise locations and U = 15 m/s.
The flow after the reattachment region remained in turbulent region from downstream to upstream since the measurement values existed on closer coordinates.

The free stream turbulent intensities over flat plate at U = 15 m/s were measured in the range of 1.5–0.7% in streamwise direction and those of blocked surface increased up to 4.7–8.1%, as seen in Figure 8. The maximum Tu values before and on the first block were obtained at the separation points, as 6.6% and 10.1%, respectively, and approximately 8.3% at the reattachment point behind the last block. The biggest turbulence levels (nearly 11%) were determined in the cavities because of the recirculation regions. These results showed that the turbulent intensities of the blocked surface were higher than those of the flat plate and took the bigger values at the separation regions, block corners and reattachments points. Figure 8.
Turbulent intensity profiles for blocked surface at 15 m/s.

The streamwise variations of pressure coefficients of the blocked surface showed similar distribution in laminar, transitional and turbulent flow, as given in Figure 9. The CP curves decreased in a certain distance at the beginning of the surface, increased up to the first block, took the minimum value at the front corner of the first block where the maximum velocities were obtained, increased on the first block and then decreased monotonically until the end of the surface. The CP increments occurred due to the flow separations, which were also emphasized with velocity and turbulent intensity profiles, and CP decreased with the free stream velocity because of the higher momentum of the fluid. Figure 9.
Pressure coefficients of blocked surface with streamwise distance at 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s.

The spanwise averaged wall temperatures and convective heat transfer coefficients, which showed reverse distribution at U = 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s are given in Figure 10(a) and (b), respectively. The maximum heat transfer coefficients were obtained at the beginning corners of the first block where the velocities had maximum values, and then decreased in the subsequent blocks. The values of heat transfer coefficient increased with the free stream velocity due to the higher turbulence level and fluid force. The average heat transfer coefficients increased up to 2.63, 2.26, 2.10 and 1.84 fold of the flat plate value at 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s respectively, so that the heat transfer enhancement became much more remarkable in the laminar than the transitional and turbulent flow, in harmony with the results of Yuan.27 Figure 10.
Dimensionless wall temperatures and heat transfer coefficients of blocked surface at 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s.

The streamwise variations of Stanton numbers on the blocks and cavities at 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s were shown in Figure 11(a) to (d) with the flat plate values. The St of the cavities were lower than those of the blocks due to the recirculation region, adverse pressure gradient and insulation from main flow, but were still higher than the flat plate values for all flow structure. The local Stanton numbers were bigger than those of flat surface 82%, 72%, 70% and 50% on the first and 52%, 45%, 44% and 33% on the last cavities, and increased up to 197%, 189%, 182% and 175% on the first and 145%, 139%, 124% and 92% on the last blocks at 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s, respectively. New empirical equations were correlated for experimental Stanton numbers of both the cavities and blocks as (3)Stx=0.0126Reh-0.276Pr-0.5(1-(x1/x)0.9)-0.406 and (4)Stx=0.0306Reh-0.313Pr-0.5(1-(x1/x)0.9)-0.391 respectively, where 4.8 × 103 ≤ Reh ≤ 2.4 × 104 and Pr = 0.707. The experimental and predicted data (equations (3–4)) with values of Stanton number on the first block and cavity are given in Table 1 for each velocity. The empirical coefficient and power indices were obtained by the least-squares method and the empirical St values showed parallelism with the experimental data within a maximum error of ±8%. Figure 11.
Streamwise variation of experimental Stanton numbers on the blocks and cavities at 3, 5, 10 and 15 m/s.
Table 1.
Values of parameters for Stanton numbers and deviations.
U (m/s) Reh (–) Pr (–) xl/x (–) Experimental Correlation Deviation (%)
Stx (–) Stx (–)
Block I 3 4.8 × 103 0.707 0.970 0.0114 0.0106 7.96
5 7.9 × 103 0.707 0.977 0.0092 0.0100 −7.59
10 1.6 × 104 0.707 0.984 0.0088 0.0092 −4.73
15 2.4 × 104 0.707 0.985 0.0082 0.0083 −1.73
Cavity I 3 4.8 × 103 0.707 0.949 0.0051 0.0050 1.08

10 1.6 × 104 0.707 0.972 0.0047 0.0046 1.76
15 2.4 × 104 0.707 0.973 0.0039 0.0042 −6.94

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The findings of present works, in which the effects of the free stream velocity on the flow and heat transfer characteristics over flat and blocked surfaces were investigated, can be summarized as follows:
In the primary flat plate measurements, the flow showed laminar, transitional and turbulent character at 3, 5 and 10 and 15 m/s, respectively.
The flows over the blocked surface separated downstream of the first block, re-circulated in the cavities and reattached upstream of the last block. The laminar flow caused earlier separation before the first block and later reattachment behind the last block, while attachment on the first block was not changed with flow structure.
The turbulent intensities of the blocked surface were measured in the range of 1.7–11% at U = 15 m/s, which were higher than those of the flat plate, and the bigger values were determined at the separation regions, reattachment points and block corners.
The pressure coefficient curves showed similar distribution in laminar, transitional and turbulent flow. The CP values increased at the separation regions, and decreased with the free stream velocity and took the minimum values at the maximum velocity points.
The heat transfer values of the cavities were smaller than those of the top faces of the blocks, but still bigger than the flat plate values for all free stream velocities. The maximum heat transfer were obtained at the front corner of the first block and then decreased in the subsequent blocks, while the minimum values were found behind the last block.
The average Stanton numbers were higher than those of the flat surface by 163% in laminar, 126% and 110% in transitional, and 84% in turbulent flows. The new empirical equations of the local Stanton numbers had been correlated for 4.8 × 103 ≤ Reh ≤ 2.4 × 104.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

def.p: length of the recirculation region before the first block (mm)
reattachment length of the recirculation region behind the last block (mm)
length of the recirculation region on the first block (mm)
